Editor's choice paper Non-precious metal catalysts supported on high Zr loaded-SBA-15 for lean NO reduction Aghil Sabbaghi Frank Leung-Yuk Lam Xijun Hu ⁎ Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Clear Water Bay, Kowloon, Hong Kong Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Hong Kong University of Science and Technology Clear Water Bay Kowloon Hong Kong ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Various non-precious metal (M=Co, Ni, Cu, and Ag) catalysts supported on high Zr-loaded SBA-15 were developed for lean NO reduction. Several properties such as mesoporous structure, high specific area, moderate surface acidity, homogenous dispersion of Zr and M species, and strong interaction between support and doped metals were investigated by various techniques. The NO reduction efficiency of the developed catalysts in the propene selective reduction of NO was in the order of Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Cu-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP in the temperature range of 250–450°C. Amongst, Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP displayed 42%, 55% and 46% N2 yield at 300, 350 and 400°C, respectively, in the dry feed whereas a slight decrease was observed in the wet feed. The catalyst activity improved significantly when a higher ratio of hydrocarbon to NO ( C N = 8 ) with the minimum fuel penalty (1%) was applied. The catalyst activity increased to 68% and 71% of NO conversion to N2 at 350 and 400°C, respectively, in the presence of water vapor. The catalyst showed excellent hydrothermal stability and durability during prolonged reaction so that 68% of N2 yield was achieved in the extreme condition in the presence of 5.3 vol% of water vapor at 400°Cfor 96h. Keywords Catalyst NOx reduction C3H6-SCR Zr-SBA-15 Fuel penalty 1 Introduction Against the backdrop of increasing demand for fuel efficiency and severe strictures placed on NOx emission standards in recent years, the demand for fuel-efficient (lean-burn) and clean-exhaust engines has been growing. NOx can be reduced by traditional three-way catalysts effectively in standard gasoline engine exhausts when the ratio of air to fuel is regulated in the stoichiometric range. However, it cannot operate beyond the stoichiometric conditions when higher concentration of oxygen for complete combustion is used [1]. However, it has been found that the hydrocarbon selective catalytic reduction (HC-SCR) catalyst can reduce NOx to N2 and O2 in the lean-burn exhaust conditions. So far, various catalytic systems have been developed for HC-SCR such as zeolite, precious metal and metal oxide based- catalysts. Among them, silver supported on alumina (Ag/Al2O3) has been the most promising catalyst for practical applications. However, Ag/Al2O3 suffers from negligible activity at low temperature due to insufficient hydrothermal stability [2,3]. Therefore, the development of new catalysts for lean NOx reduction (LNR) is still called for. Recently, mesoporous materials such as SBA-15 and MCM-41 have been of interest owing to their pore volume, large surface area and hydrothermal stability to be used as catalyst or support in various gas and liquid catalytic reactions. Pt/MCM-41, Pt/Al-MCM-41 and Pt/Ru/MCM-41 have been employed for LNR with propane and propene. Among them, 1% Pt/MCM-41 exhibited ∼50% NO conversion at 220°C in the presence of propene [4,5]. The reaction window has been widened as a result of Ru introduction to the catalyst (1% Pt/5% Ru/MCM-41). However, the crystal structure of MCM-41 declined in prolonged exposure to the hydrothermal conditions [6]. Subsequently, Pt supported on the modified SBA-15 with Al has been used for LNR catalytic systems to overcome the hydrothermal instability of MCM-41. 10wt% Pt/Al-SBA-15 showed 33.3% and 42.3% NO conversion to N2 and N2O, respectively at 250°C. However, using high amount of precious metals (Ru and Pt) is associated with two major disadvantages; not only does it drastically increase the cost of the catalytic system development but also a significant amount of N2O gas (greenhouse gas) forms during the reaction [4,5]. Therefore, developing a cost-effective and more environmentally-friendly catalyst with high SCR activity and N2 selectivity is still very much in demand. Among various mesoporous materials, Zr-SBA-15 has several important properties such as high surface area, surface acidity, excellent hydrothermal stability and strong interaction with an introduced metal, which are essential for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx [6]. Transition metals (Co, Ni) supported on Zr-SBA-15 have been used for H8C3-SCR by Sabbaghi et al. [7,8]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the presence of propene as the main component (27.5 mass%) of the unburned hydrocarbons in gasoline engine exhausts [9] as well as the effect of a wider variety of transition metals such as Co, Ni, Cu and Ag loaded on Zr-SBA-15 for C3H6-SCR have not been reported yet. Hence, the performance of the transition metal (Cu, Co, Ni, and Ag) catalysts supported on high Zr loaded-SBA-15 in the propene selective catalytic reduction of NO was investigated in this study. 2 Experimental 2.1 Support preparation The details on the preparation procedure of support can be found elsewhere [7,8]. The following is a brief summary: In the first step, Zr-SBAD is prepared using the direct synthesis method. 3.35g of amphiphilic triblock copolymer P123 (EO20PO70EO20), as the structure directing agent, is dissolved in 125ml hydrochloric acid solution at pH=1.3. Then a calculated amount of ZrONO3·xH2O is added to the solution before adding 7g of tetraethyl orthosilicate for obtaining the desired Si/Al ratio of 10. The mixture is stirred for 24h at 35°C. Afterwards, the solution is transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and ages at 100°C for 24h under static conditions. The final product, Zr-SBAD, is filtrated, washed several times with deionized water, dried at 60°C overnight and calcined at 600°Cfor 8h with a heating rate of 1°Cmin−1. In the second step, 1.2g of Zr-SBAD and 2ml of zirconium (IV) propoxide [Zr(n-PrO)4] (70wt% solution in 1-propanol) are added to 8ml of absolute ethanol. The mixture is stirred overnight under the nitrogen atmosphere at room temperature. The mixture is filtered and washed with absolute ethanol three times to remove excess Zr(n-PrO)4. The solid material, Zr-SBADP, is recovered by filtration and dried overnight at room temperature prior to calcination at 550°C for 6h with a heating rate 1°Cmin−1. SBA-15 is prepared according to the method described elsewhere [10]. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.5wt% of transition metal catalysts supported on Zr-SBADP, M (Co, Cu, Ni, and Ag)-2.5-Zr-SBADP were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation technique [11]. A required volume of aqueous solution of cobalt, copper and nickel acetate, and silver nitrate was impregnated into the support to obtain 2.5wt% of M on the Zr-SBADP. The impregnated supports were dried overnight at 70°C and calcined at 550°Cfor 5h in the tube furnace with a heating rate of 1°Cmin−1. For comparison purposes, 2.5wt% of Co catalysts supported on Zr-SBAD and SBA-15 were prepared with the same cobalt precursor, impregnation and heat treatment procedures. 2.3 Characterization Various techniques, including powder x-ray diffraction technique (XRD), nitrogen adsorption and desorption, x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and x-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) were applied for the characterization of catalysts and supports. The crystallinity of the materials was investigated by means of PANalytical X-ray diffractometer (model Xpert Pro) and powder x-ray diffraction system (model PW1830 (Philips), 2kW, Cu anode, graphite monochromator). The scanning range (2θ) was adjusted in the range of 0.3–3° and 10–90° for low and high angle spectra, respectively. The specific surface area of the supports and catalysts was determined via N2 adsorption–desorption by a Coulter SA3100 surface area analyzer at liquid nitrogen temperature. The required amount of samples (0.1g) was outgassed at 250°C for 120min prior to the analysis. Linear region of the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation (relative pressure between 0.05 and 0.22) and relative pressure of 0.98 were considered for the specific surface area and total pore volume measurement, respectively. The surface chemistry of the materials was analyzed by a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD multi-technique XPS instrument under ultra-high vacuum where the energy source was a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (excitation energy, hυ=1486.6eV) at a voltage of 10kV and a current of 15mA. The low and high resolution spectra were obtained at 70 and 20eV pass energy, respectively. The collected spectra were corrected by C (1s) at a binding energy of 284.6eV as reference. A JEOL JSX-3201Z XRF instrument was used for determining the elemental composition of the prepared supports and catalysts. The x-ray source for the experiments was acquired when the voltage and current of the tube was adjusted at 30kV and 0–1mA, respectively. A pulse chromatographic technique was used for surface acidity measurement. The experiment was performed in gas-phase at 300°C. The total acidity (sum of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites) and Brönsted acid sites were measured by the adsorption of pyridine (PY) and 2,6-dimethylpyridine (DMPY) as probe molecules (basic compounds), respectively [28]. 0.05g of sample was loaded in a micro reactor and fed by a very small amount of probe molecules. The adsorption of PY and DMPY compounds continue into the saturation level from where the probe molecules can be detected by a GC. Therefore, the amount of adsorbed PY and DMPY can be measured. 2.4 Catalytic tests The catalytic activities of M (Co, Ni, Cu, and Ag)-2.5-Zr-SBADP, Co-2.5-Zr-SBAD and Co-2.5-SBA-15 catalysts in the selective catalytic reduction of NO by propene were evaluated continuously at atmospheric pressure in a fixed bed stainless steel reactor at steady-state conditions. Typically, 0.5g of catalyst was packed in the reactor and fed by a gas mixture consisting of 553ppm of NO, 553 and 1500ppm of C3H6 to provide C N = 3 and 8 , respectively, 0.0–5.3 vol% of H2O, and 5.3 vol% of O2 (balanced in He) with the total flow rate of 150 mlmin−1 (GHSV ≈18000h−1). The reactor was placed in a Carbolite tube furnace to provide the desired temperature for the reaction. The furnace temperature was controlled by an additional thermocouple. The concentration of N2, CO2, N2O in the reaction effluent was analyzed by a GC (Agilent 7890B) equipped with Porapak Q, Hayesep D columns and TCD and FID detectors. The effect of catalyst composition such as the type of transition metals, reaction temperature and reactants concentration on the catalyst performance in C3H6-SCR were studied. The performance of the catalyst in NO and C3H6 conversion was calculated as follows: NO conversion to N 2 = 2 × [ N 2 ] o u t l e t × 100 [ NO ] in C 3 H 6 conversion to CO x = ( [ C 3 H 6 ] i n l e t − [ C 3 H 6 ] o u t l e t ) × 100 [ C 3 H 6 ] i n l e t 3 Results 3.1 Characterization of the supports and catalysts Low and high angle XRD patterns of the supports and catalyst are presented in Fig. 1 a and b, respectively. Three distinct peaks related to (100), (110) and (200) planes can be seen through the low angle patterns indicating that all samples are characterized by a p6 mm hexagonal symmetry, which is known as a mesoporous structure of pure silica SBA-15. However, the intensity of the peaks slightly decreases from Zr-SBADP to M-2.5-Zr-SBADP catalysts. High angle XRD pattern of the supports and M-2.5-Zr-SBADP catalyst showed that diffraction peaks at 2θ=30°, 35°, 50°and 60° related to tetragonal crystalline phase of ZrO2 were not present. In addition, no crystalline phase of Co [7], Ni [12], Cu [13] and Ag [14] species were detected by the high angle XRD experiment on the corresponding catalysts. The absence of metal oxide diffraction peaks in various supports and catalysts XRD patterns could be assigned either to the size of oxide species, which was smaller than the detection limit of XRD, or dispersed throughout the supports structure, be it on the surface or into the framework, homogeneously [8,12]. The physical and chemical properties of the supports and catalysts are tabulated in Table 1 . The specific surface area and pore volume of the supports decreased as a result of incorporating Zr species into the SBA-15 structure. The decreasing trend is almost proportional to the amount of Zr incorporated into the support structure, where Zr-SBADP with the highest Zr content showed the lowest surface area (548m2 g−1) and pore volume (0.7cm3 g−1). In addition, the introduction of the transition metals into the Zr-SBADP resulted in a slight decrease in the surface area and pore volume of the catalysts. Moreover, nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. S1) confirms that the developed catalysts possess a mesoporous structure with a highly uniform size distribution [15]. The acidity of the catalytic system as a key role player in HC-SCR [16–18] was measured and tabulated in Table 1. Both Brönsted and Lewis acid sites were observed on the supports and catalysts. The quantity of the acid sites was directly proportional to the Zr content in the supports where Zr-SBADP and Zr-SBAD with the highest and lowest Zr content, respectively, showed 136 and 128μmolg−1 of total acidity, respectively. A similar observation has been reported elsewhere [19–21]. The acidity of M-2.5-Zr-SBADP catalysts slightly changed after metal loading. Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP exhibited the highest total acidity (133μmolg−1) and Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP showed the lowest total acidity (120μmolg−1). The XPS results for the support and catalysts are presented in Fig. 2 a–e. The binding energy of Zr core line 3d5/2 of Zr-SBADP (Fig. 2a) was equal to 183.4eV, which was higher than that of bulk ZrO2 (182.4eV [22–24]). A similar binding energy with a slight difference was observed in the developed catalysts. The binding energies of Zr core line 3d5/2 of Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP, Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP, Cu-2.5-Zr-SBADP and Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP were 183.3, 183, 182.8 and 182.6eV, respectively (not presented herein). These results indicate that the loading of transition metals led to a slight decrease in the biding energy of Zr3d5/2 in Zr-SBADP. The charge transfer from the M metal to Zr can increase the electron cloud on Zr, which in turn brings about a decrease in the binding energy of Zr3d5/2. The binding energies (BEs) of Ni core line 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP (Fig. 2b) were measured at 856 and 873eV, respectively. These species cannot be identified as bulk NiO, since NiO species are known to have Ni 2p3/2 binding energies of 853eV. However, the present species are similar to NiSiO3 phase with BEs of 856.1eV [25]. The same phenomenon was observed in Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP, where the core level binding energies of Co2p3/2 and Co2p1/2 were centered at 782.3 and 798.1eV, respectively (Fig. 2c). Two satellite peaks corresponding to Co2p3/2 and Co2p1/2 were emerged at 786.8 and 803.7eV, respectively. The core level binding energy values associated with satellite shake-up features indicate that the cobalt species are present with the oxidation state of (II) in the catalyst [26]. However, these species were different from the cobalt oxide with BEs of 779.4eV and 794.9eV corresponding to the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively [27]. In all probability, the existing species are similar to cobalt silicate species, which are known to have Co2p3/2 binding energies of ∼781.5 eV[28]. The XPS results for the copper species (Fig. 2d) showed that the state of species is different from the two aforementioned catalysts. The BEs of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 were centered at 932 and 952eV, respectively, indicating the presence of CuO phase in the Cu-2.5-Zr-SBADP catalyst. In addition, the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 lever showed a 20.1eV gap, which can be observed in CuO standard spectrum [29]. The BEs of Ag 3d5/2 and the distance between Ag 3d5/2 peak and Ag 3d3/2 peak were evaluated for Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP catalyst (Fig. 2e). The binding energies of Ag core line 3d5/2 and the peak-to-peak distance were measured at around 367.6eV and 6eV, respectively. These results verify the existence of Ag+ species in the catalyst structure, which is in good agreement with the literature [30]. The XPS results for the supports and catalysts are further verified by high angle XRD patterns (Fig. 1b), where no diffraction peaks related to agglomerate metal oxides were detected. This validates the presence of the strong interaction of Co and Ni species with the support in the case of Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP and Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP, and dispersion of metal oxide species with a size smaller than XRD detection limit, in the case of Cu-2.5-Zr-SBADP and Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP catalysts. The physical and chemical properties of the developed catalytic systems such as large surface area, surface acidity and strong interaction of active metals and the support, which are essential for HC-SCR reaction [17,18,31], all point out to the fact that the developed catalysts could exhibit activity in the propene selective catalytic reduction of NO. 3.2 Catalytic activity The performance of the developed catalysts was investigated by a fixed bed reactor, which is shown in Fig. 3 .The NOx reduction over the catalysts, except the supported Ag catalyst, follows a typical volcano shape VS temperature so that the maximum NO reduction was observed at 300–350°C. Afterward, the NOx reduction decreased when the hydrocarbon combustion reaction became dominant. The sole support (Zr-SBADP) did not exhibit any reduction activity at different temperatures. Introduction of 2.5wt% of cobalt into the support (Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP) considerably increased the NO reduction over the entire temperature range. NO conversion to N2 started at 250°C with a value of 20% and increased to 42% and 55% when the temperature rose to 300 and 350°C, respectively. However, the catalyst activity for the NO reduction decreased at above 350°C with a rate of 46% and 24% conversion at 400 and 450°C, respectively. The Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP catalyst showed a lower NO conversion to N2 below 350°C compared to Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP. The Ni-loaded sample converted 5%, 17% and 40% of NO to N2 at 250, 300 and 350°C, respectively, and showed a 50% conversion at 400°C. However, the competing combustion reaction decreased the NO reduction to 47% at 450°C. The NO conversion to N2 over Cu-2.5-Zr-SBADP followed a similar trend of NO reduction over the two aforementioned catalysts. However, the performance of the catalyst was lower than that of Co and Ni-supported catalysts at various temperatures. The activity of the catalyst increased with temperature up to 350°C with the value of 31% at 350°C and dropped to 23% and 12%, at 400 and 450°C, respectively. Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP showed the lowest NO reduction among the developed catalysts over the entire temperature range. The catalyst showed 8% and 25% NO conversion to N2 at 400 and 450°C whereas negligible activity was observed at T≤350°C. The propene conversion to COx over the catalysts is shown in Fig. 4 . The trend for hydrocarbon conversion over various samples was similar although the low-temperature conversion (T≤350°C) was higher over the supported Co and Ni catalysts. Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP and Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP catalysts approximately reached propene conversion of ∼100% at 350 and 400°C, respectively. The catalyst doped with 2.5wt% Cu showed a lower conversion of HC than the two aforementioned catalysts at different temperatures. The catalyst reached the propene conversion of 85% and 100% at 400 and 450°C, respectively. Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP exhibited the lowest conversion of propene compared to the other developed catalysts. A 25% and 62% of propene conversion was achieved over the catalyst at 350 and 400°C, respectively, whereas no HC conversion was observed at T≤350°C. As many developed catalysts are active in NO oxidation to NO2 which in turn lead to significant improvement in their lean NOx reduction performance [32,33], the oxidation activity of M-2.5-Zr-SBADP was evaluated during the HC-SCR reaction in the absence of propene. The results (not presented herein) revealed that NO was the dominant NOx species over all the catalysts in the temperature range of 250–450°C. Since a large amount of water vapor is present in car exhaust which leads to adverse impact on the catalyst performance [34], the activity of two most active catalysts (Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP and Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP) in the presence of water vapor was evaluated. The results are shown in Fig. 5 . The trend for the NO reduction over the catalysts was similar to that in the absence of water vapor (Fig. 4). A slight decrease in NO reduction was observed over Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP at T≤350°C. The catalyst showed a 33% and 47.5% N2 yield at 300 and 350°C, respectively. However, the catalyst activity was not affected in the presence of water vapor at T>350°C. The catalyst exhibited 52% and 30% of NO reduction to N2 at 400 and 450°C, respectively. The efficiency of Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP was more affected than the cobalt-supported catalyst as a result of water vapor over the entire temperature range. NO conversion dropped to 36.5% and 42% at 400 and 450°C, respectively. The decreasing trend was more pronounced at T≤350°C. Recently, hydrogen production via on-board fuel reforming and using an additional fuel injection has been investigated as an attempt to increase NOx conversion efficiency at a low temperature range. However, this approach can lead to an unacceptable fuel penalty with a subsequent additional fuel injection as well as significant hardware changes [35,36]. However, in this study, the increasing amount of available reducing agent was considered as an effective approach to achieve a higher NOx reduction. In view of this, Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP, as the most active developed catalyst, was considered for further investigation in the presence of a higher concentration of HC. The performance of the catalyst was evaluated in the presence of 1500ppm of C3H6 ( C N ≈ 8 ) while other conditions were regulated with 533ppm of NO, 5.3 vol% of O2, 5.3 vol% of H2O in helium as balance with a total flow rate of 150mlmin−1 (Fig. 6 ). NO conversion increase was negligible as the C3H6 concentration increased from 533ppm to 1500ppm at T≤300°C. However, the catalyst activity significantly increased to 68%, 71% and 60% of NO conversion to N2 at 350, 400 and 450°C, respectively. It is well known that possessing a high NOx conversion efficiency does not necessarily render a catalyst suitability for practical conditions. The catalytic system should possess hydrothermal and long-term stability to tolerate the extreme conditions of the car exhaust. Subsequently, the prolonged reaction was carried out over Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP for 96h at 400°C in the presence of water vapor (Fig. 7 ). The catalyst managed to retain its activity without any significant deactivation after 72h at 400°C. The catalyst showed a 68% of N2 yield after 72h and maintained it for 96h. 3.3 Discussion The hydrocarbon selective catalytic reduction of NO consists of several sequential reactions as follows (the details of the complete reaction is under investigation). NO+O2 results in the formation of surface nitrates ( N O 3 − ), nitrites ( N O 2 − ) and nitrosonium ions (NO+), which can combine with activated hydrocarbon molecules on the surface of the catalyst to form organic nitro (RNO2), nitrito (R O NO) and nitroso compounds (RNO). These surface species are converted into oxime species (RNOH) throughout several surface reactions prior to isocyanate (RNCO) formation. Isocyanates react with water to form NH3 and R — NH2 with the subsequent formation of N2. In addition, oxidation of NO to NO2 over the catalyst with the subsequent formation of the surface nitrates and nitrites species can be considered as well. Theses surface species can react with partial oxidized hydrocarbon species to form N2, H2O and CO2 as final products. Furthermore, direct oxidation of hydrocarbon, as a competitive reaction regardless of the aforementioned reaction routes, occurs during HC-SCR [37,38]. The activity trend of catalysts can be explained more in detail herein. The significant difference in the activity of the catalysts could not be assigned to the oxidation of NO to NO2 since NO was the dominant species during oxidation experiment over the various catalysts (data not shown here). However, the surface acidity including Brönsted and Lewis acidity could be affect the activity. Lewis acid sites act as active sites for the formation of surface nitrates ( N O 3 − ) and nitrites ( N O 2 − ), which can be combined with the activated hydrocarbons species over the M sites in order to proceed the reaction chains, resulting in the conversion of NO to nitrogen in HC-SCR [16]. Fig. 3 shows that the performance of Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP was higher than Co-2.5-SBA-15 over the studied temperature range. As can be seen, the support which was used for Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP was different from that for Co-2.5-SBA-15 (Zr-SBADP versus SBA-15). Zr-SBADP carries high amount of surface acidity (132μmolg−1) (Table 1) while the acidity of SBA-15 is negligible [39]. Thus, it can be concluded that the presence of acid sites could result in a significant elevation in the amount of NOx adsorbed, which in turn promotes the overall reduction of NO to N2. A similar observation has been reported elsewhere [16–18]. Furthermore, the acidity of the support can enhance the interaction of the support and doped metals [40]. The interaction between doped metals and supports seems to affect several properties of the catalyst [41]. Strong metal-support interaction enhances the value of the exposed surface metallic active sites, which can be accompanied with the catalyst performance enhancement [42,43]. This can be validated by BET results (Table 1), where the specific surface area and pore volume were in the order of Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP≈ Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Cu-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP. Moreover, it is well known that a strong interaction between the support and M can facilitate the flow of electrons through the catalyst structure [44]. AS HC-SCR reaction consists of several oxidation and reduction reactions [38], it could be promoted by smooth charge transfer. In addition, the ease of charge transferring facilitates the production of surface activated hydrocarbon species over M sites. This step can proceed when hydrocarbon molecules are activated on metal oxide sites through the CH bonds. The bond can be cleaved via the direct interaction of σ and σ*-orbitals of CH bond with d-orbitals of transition metal cations [45,46]. The electron configuration study reveals that the number of unpaired and empty 3d orbitals which can participate in bond cleaving is in the order of Co>Ni>Cu, which can affect the activity of the metals in CH bond cleavage. Moreover, XPS results (Fig. 2d and e) showed that the oxidation state of Cu and Ag was +2 and +1, respectively, which in turn brings about unfilled 3d orbitals for the former and filled 4d orbitals for the latter cation. In addition, the radius of Cu and Ag can affect the electron affinity of the cations as well. The charge affinity of Cu2+ is stronger than Ag1+. Accordingly, the electron configuration illustrates that the probability of the formation of activated propene species over the developed catalysts can be in the order of Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Cu-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP, which is according to the order of the catalyst activity (Fig. 3 and 4). On the other hand, the possibility of CH bond cleavage can be ascribed to the sticking property of the propene on the catalyst surface, too. The sticking property is directly proportional to the sticking coefficient while exponentially depends on dissociative chemisorption energy of the molecule on the surface. The dissociation energy of CH4 over Co, Ni, Cu and Ag is 0.09, −0.13, 3.06 and 6.31eV, respectively [47]. As can be seen, the dissociation energy over Co and Ni are lower than that of Cu and Ag. In addition, the dissociation energy can be smaller for heavier hydrocarbons than methane [48]. Furthermore, the required activation energy of the chemically dissociated molecules over a metal is proportional to the dissociation energy used based on the Brönsted–Evans–Polanyi (BEP) relation, which has been verified for metal oxides, too [49,50]. Therefore, the propene can be activated more easily over Co and Ni than Cu and Ag (Figs. 3 and 4). In addition, the relative sticking probability of propene over Co and Ni species is higher than that of Cu and Ag species as a result of the lower dissociation energy required. It can be concluded that the lower required activation energy and higher sticking probability of propene led to an increase in the rate of NO reduction over the supported Co and Ni catalysts compared to Cu-2.5-Ze-SBADP and Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP (Fig. 3). The investigation of the effect of water vapor on the catalyst efficiency over Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP and Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP, as the two most active catalysts in this study, revealed that a slight inhibition effect of water vapor was observed over the supported Co catalyst even though it was more pronounced over Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP (Fig. 5). Catalyst performance declining could be assigned to partially covering the active sites (Zr and Co) by water vapor. However, the performance of the catalysts, especially Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP, is comparable to that of the zeolite-based catalyst. It is well known that zeolite based-catalysts are very sensitive to water vapor. For instance, Cu/Y zeolite has shown a 32% decrease in NO reduction in the presence of water vapor in C3H6-SCR at 325°C [34,51]. This phenomenon has been attributed to the dealumination and modification of the metallic active site geometry of the zeolite structure as a result of water vapor [34,51]. However, Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP maintained its activity in a way that only a 11% activity declining was observed at 350°C. Furthermore, no suppression occurred at T>350°C (Fig. 6). This result further implies that the catalyst possesses a very stable crystal structure and strong interaction with the active sites (Co and Zr) such that the catalyst structure did no change even after a prolonged reaction experiment. The low and high angle XRD pattern of the fresh and used catalyst (Fig. S2) further verified the stability of the catalyst because no significant changes could be observed through the XRD pattern. As the supported Co catalyst exhibited better activity than Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP at T≤400°C, activity enhancement was studied using a higher ratio of carbon to nitrogen. The result (Fig. 6) showed that the activity had significantly improved following the use of C N = 8 in the temperature range of 350–450°C. NOx reduction enhancement as a result of using a higher concentration of HC is in good agreement with the available literature [7,52,53]. The abundance of reducing agents leads to a significant increase in intermediate species (CxHyOz) formation, which in turn improves the overall rate of the NOx reduction to N2 [8,34]. Subsequent results of using C N = 8 over Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP are comparable with the results of using C N = 8 over Ag/Al2O3 as a promising catalyst for HC-SCR [35,36]. It has been reported that the high NOx conversion has been achieved over Ag/Al2O3 as of result of introducing Pt into the catalyst, using hydrogen (1000ppm) from the on-board H2 tank or hydrogen production using the fuel reforming system to provide H2 and a high concentration of C to N ( C N = 12 ). It should be noted that using such a high amount of HC leads to a fuel penalty of about 2% [35,36]. In addition, using a noble metal increases the cost of the catalytic system development significantly. Furthermore, H2 injection as a result of on-board fuel processing leads to an unacceptable fuel penalty as well as a significant amount of hardware change [35,36]. However, Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP showed comparable activity using a higher concentration of HC with a fuel penalty of 1% and adding Pt and H2 was not required. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited an excellent long-term stability in the activity and crystal structure (Fig. 7 and Fig. S2, respectively), which is necessary for the real-world application in the LNR catalytic system. 4 Conclusion Non-precious metal catalysts supported on high Zr loaded-SBA-15 with a metal loading of 2.5wt%,M (Co, Ni, Cu and Ag)-2.5-Zr-SBADP, were developed successfully and applied for propene LNR. The NO reduction efficiencies of the catalysts were in the order of Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Cu-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP. Among these catalysts, Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP exhibited a superior activity at T≤400°C, which is a desired temperature range for LNR. The catalyst showed a 48% and 52% NO conversion to N2 at 350 and 400°C, respectively, whereas a 20% and 37% N2 yield was observed at the same temperature range over Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP under dry feeding. The activity enhancement achieved via a higher concentration of available HC over the Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP catalyst in a high fuel economy (fuel penalty≤1%) condition. The NO reduction efficiency of the catalyst improved significantly. The catalyst exhibited a 68% and 71% NO conversion to N2 at 350 and 400°C, respectively, in the presence of water vapor. The results of the long-term stability experiment revealed that the catalyst managed to maintain its high efficiency (68% of NO conversion) for a prolonged time, i.e. 96h. coredata.dc:description: Various non-precious metal (M=Co, Ni, Cu, and Ag) catalysts supported on high Zr-loaded SBA-15 were developed for lean NO reduction. Several properties such as mesoporous structure, high specific area, moderate surface acidity, homogenous dispersion of Zr and M species, and strong interaction between support and doped metals were investigated by various techniques. The NO reduction efficiency of the developed catalysts in the propene selective reduction of NO was in the order of Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Ni-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Cu-2.5-Zr-SBADP>Ag-2.5-Zr-SBADP in the temperature range of 250–450°C. Amongst, Co-2.5-Zr-SBADP displayed 42%, 55% and 46% N2 yield at 300, 350 and 400°C, respectively, in the dry feed whereas a slight decrease was observed in the wet feed. The catalyst activity improved significantly when a higher ratio of hydrocarbon to NO ( C N = 8 ) with the minimum fuel penalty (1%) was applied. The catalyst activity increased to 68% and 71% of NO conversion to N2 at 350 and 400°C, respectively, in the presence of water vapor. The catalyst showed excellent hydrothermal stability and durability during prolonged reaction so that 68% of N2 yield was achieved in the extreme condition in the presence of 5.3 vol% of water vapor at 400°Cfor 96h.
coredata.dc:title: Non-precious metal catalysts supported on high Zr loaded-SBA-15 for lean NO reduction
